paragraphs: Margaret Kerwin is the first of her siblings to leave Ireland. By 24, she's been in the United States for four years and just married to Irish-born John Lawlor.

images.alt: A scanned photograph of a brick factory along a set of railroad tracks

paragraphs: A gritty industrial city of approximately 100,000, situated at the Naugatuck and Mad Rivers in central Connecticut, Waterbury had been the center of the American brass industry since the early 19th century.

images.alt: A handdrawn map of the city in 1899.

paragraphs: Margaret's younger sister, Katie, moves in with her family. A single 23-year-old, Katie starts a job at American Mills.
It's not uncommon for immigrants to follow their families into the United States, putting down roots in small neighborhoods resembling their close-knit communities back home.

images.alt: A modest 3-story home with a pink exterior and metal fence.

paragraphs: Margaret's home, built in 1885, is one of those packed immigrant households. Her modest 3-story home contains 500-square-foot floors in which she crams 5 children, her husband, and her sister.

heading: One in, one out
paragraphs: In the same year that Margaret's family moves away to Philadelphia, the girls' brother James follows in from Ireland. He takes over the rented house with Katie.
Katie moves out of the shared apartment when James marries Hannah Murphy.
As James and Hannah start their family, James's brother Martin moves into the city with his wife, Elizabeth Bergin, and their son, John Joseph.
Martin had been living in Naugatuck, a neighboring town, since his arrival in 1900. He married Elizabeth in 1903, and they had John in 1905.
Katie moves again, this time with her new husband, Thomas J. Byrne.

Martin John Kerwin, who had been living in neighboring Naugatuck since he arrived in the States in 1907, moves into the city, where he begins work at the Rogers & Brother silverware manufacturing company.
In the same year, his brother, Michael, moves into Waterbury as well, joined by his wife, Bridget Agnes Murphy, and their newborn, John Francis.

heading: Triple Deckers
paragraphs: Waterbury was a city of close-knit, ethnic neighborhoods, where many residents remained their entire lives. In 1928, Martin moved to a 3-story home on Pleasant St, where his children would raise their families as well.
